Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: Investigating E Region Auroral Irregularities with Coherent and Incoherent Scatter Radar and Optics
Award.AbstractNarration: This project is to investigate the small scale structure and temporal evolution of plasma perturbations in the auroral ionosphere near 100 km (the E-region). This effort will utilize both theory and experimental data analysis in order to characterize the relationship between the plasma irregularities and the background ionospheric state as well as investigate their utility for diagnosing small-scale and short-lived features in the regional plasma convection pattern. Measurements of E-region irregularities will be acquired from a coherent scatter radar imager, which will be relocated near the Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar (PFISR) in Alaska for coincident, common-volume estimates of electric fields, temperatures, densities, and neutral winds in the E-region ionosphere. Quantitative analysis of these state parameters in conjunction with theoretical modeling will target investigations on auroral-zone wave heating, irregularity aspect sensitivity, preferred irregularity altitude, Farley-Buneman wave phase speed saturation, auroral convection, neutral wind effects, thermal instabilities, and the relationship between the radio aurora and discrete optical auroral forms based on comparisons with simultaneous white-light imagery. This project will support an upcoming NSF-supported CubeSat mission as well as undergraduate and graduate student education and training in observational and theoretical aeronomy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involves the Aurora Borealis. Many people are familiar with the dazzling lights display associated with the aurora. Less well known is the appearance of the aurora in radar imagery, the so-called "radio aurora." In fact, the radio aurora has been known to interfere with radio communications for almost a century. Amateur radio operators are familiar with auroral backscatter. The phenomenon is plainly visible in radars capable of making spatial images of the backscatter.

Under this project, researchers at Cornell University and the University of Alaska, Anchorage deployed a small research radar on the Kenai Peninsula. The radar is situated so as to be able to observe the aurora directly over Fairbanks where a number of research facilities are located. Through signal processing, imagery is derived from the radar data during times when the geomagnetic disturbances and the aurora is present.

The intellectual merit of the research lies in inferring from the radar data how the ionospheric plasma waves that form naturally during disturbed periods and that give rise to radar backscatter behave. We are particularly interested in quantifying the conditions under which they occur and the properties of the backsctter spectra they engender. The research is done in the context of mathematical and computational models of the underlying plasma waves.

The broader impact of the research resides in the application of the radar imagery to the larger problem of geomagnetic disturbances and their terrestrial impacts. We have developed means of inferring the electric field in the ionosphere from the radar data with fine spatial and temporal resolution. As the ionospheric electric field mediates the transfer of energy from space to Earth during geomagnetic storms, this kind of measurement has important practical benefits.
